Message.Title: comparing Oracle vs IBM, Oracle is much cheaper?
Message.Msg: I like Oracle better in terms of valuation and growth. They are both around 10 forward P/E but IBM will have the restructuring charge this coming two quarters. Oracle bit IBM both on gross margin and net margin. PEG ratio, IBM is lower than Oracle as well. What do you think?

Topic.Title: comparing Oracle vs IBM, Oracle is much cheaper?

Message.Msg: ORCL is a great company. It has much higher overall margins because of the larger % of software in its sales. In lean times, ORCL will see earnings go down faster than IBM as was the case in 2009. IBM's revenue base is moire diversified than ORCL when you consider Services and Finance - GFS. ORCL trades at about 3.75x its sales while IBM trades around 2x sales reflecting IBM's lower margins and slower growth. So I can't agree that ORCL is much cheaper. Interestingly for this year, the composite analyst estimate for ORCL operating earnings is around 8% growth while IBM's estimate is closer to 9%.

I worked at IBM for 30+ years and you are right, the employees are under skilled but IBM is largely responsible for that. They rarely allow employees to leave one division/organization to join another where they could hone their skills and most of them never have to deal with real world customer problems and implementations. IBM could fix things by rotating people in and out of positions and training them but there is no budget anymore for any of that. In addition, there are tons of chiefs and very few Indians (to coin an old phrase). I now work at a company that is a lot more customer oriented and I have learned so much more in the last 5 years doing this that it is amazing. But IBM is like other large organizations now, they are driven by quarter to quarter results so no one dares to ask for more money to do things the right way.
It is fact that IBM now has less than 100,000 employees in the US, just FYI. Maybe IBM doesn't officially release this, but it has been leaked several times over the last couple of years.
